column1: The U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) prepared this report as required by the Foreign
Assistance Act of 1961 (P.L. 87-195), Section 634, as amended.
The report is compiled under contract on behalf of the Knowledge Management branch of USAID’s
Data reported in this publication may also be obtained from the USAID web site at www.usaid.gov. Look
under “Who We Are”, then “Transparency”. The "Greenbook" link is located under the “USAID’s Foreign
Aid Explorer” heading. The US Overseas Loans and Grants (Greenbook) web page allows users to
download the data used in the publication. The direct link is https://explorer.usaid.gov/reports-
The data in this report is provided by United States Government departments and independent offices.
USAID welcomes comments regarding the contents and format of this report. Please direct
correspondence to: Bureau for Legislative and Public Affairs; U.S. Agency for International Development;

column1: The annual update of the “U.S. Overseas Loans and Grants”, informally known as the “Greenbook”, contains
summary data of United States Government (USG) foreign assistance since 1945 and detailed annual data for the

column2: Foreign assistance is categorized as either economic assistance or military assistance.

column1: obligations for foreign assistance, as defined by the Foreign Assistance Act, are included regardless of
implementing mechanism (i.e. direct hires, contracts, grants, government-to-government). Other U.S. Government

column2: The contents of each section are explained in further detail below.

column1: Foreign assistance is reported by recipient country and organized by geographic region, without distinction

column2: The report includes a world summary page, regional summary

column1: Any country which has received cumulative economic or military assistance over $500,000 since 1945 and is
considered an “Independent State” by the U.S. Department of State merits an individual country page. Generally,
country names are those officially designated by the U.S. Department of State.
country/region names and groupings can be found in the Country and Regional Notes in the back of the book.
From 2001 to the present, grant data represent net obligations and loan data represent net authorizations.
obligations may be negative if deobligations are greater than obligations during the fiscal year.
through 2000, annual data represent total new grant obligations and loan authorizations in the given fiscal year.
Prior to 1955, grant data represent net obligations and loan data represent net authorizations.
are not available, appropriations or disbursements are used. Historical data are updated and may not reconcile
with past editions of the Greenbook.
column2: All data are reported in historical U.S. dollars.
Values less than $50,000 are denoted as 0.0; a period (“.”) indicates no funding.

column2: All accounts are presented by funding

column1: agency, except for accounts funded by the Executive Office of the President, which are credited to the
For detailed annual data and dynamic visualizations, visit https://explorer.usaid.gov.
A brief explanation of the contents of each is provided below. Foreign assistance is comprised of economic and
military assistance. The economic assistance section is further divided by funding agency. For appropriations
funded by the Executive Office of the President, the program is listed under the implementing agency. The tables
provide a detailed listing of “accounts” that comprise each section and funding agency for the current year. For
the purpose of this publication, “accounts” refer to Federal appropriation accounts.
Economic assistance is defined as foreign aid for programs with a development or humanitarian objective.
Development aid programs foster sustainable, broad-based economic progress and sociopolitical stability in
developing countries. Humanitarian aid programs focus on the immediate alleviation of humanitarian
emergencies, both natural and man-made disasters, as well as problems resulting from conflict associated with
failed or failing states. Economic assistance captures U.S. voluntary contributions to multilateral organizations,
non-military security assistance, as well as humanitarian and non-military development programs funded by the
Total economic assistance is divided among the following funding categories: United States Agency for
International Development (USAID) and Predecessor, Department of Agriculture, Department of State, and Other
The USAID and Predecessor Table shows the comprehensive list of accounts that comprise the funding

forces, or aid which subsidizes or substantially enhances military capability. Military assistance excludes
humanitarian and non-military development programs funded by the U.S. Department of Defense; these

column1: Total loans and grants is the sum of annual data from 1945 to the present.

column2: Decreases in the outstanding amount reflect both repayments on loans and debt
Private loans to foreign entities that are guaranteed and/or insured by the U.S. Government are not

column1: included in this publication. However, obligations for the subsidy cost of guarantees, provided by appropriated
funds as required by the Federal Credit Reform Act of 1990, are included in the data. Claims acquired by the U.S.
Government upon default under these programs are also not included; however, capitalization of the defaults is
included. Therefore, the outstanding loan balance may be greater than total loans and grants.
Appropriation – an act of the United States Congress allowing US Federal Agencies to incur obligations for
Authorization – substantive legislation that establishes legal operation of a Federal program, either indefinitely or
for a specific period of time, and sanctions particular program funding levels.
Economic Assistance – foreign aid for programs with a development or humanitarian objective.
Fiscal Year (FY) – an accounting period of 365 days (366 in leap years), but not necessarily starting on January 1.
The fiscal year of the United States Government begins on October 1 and ends on September 30 and is
designated by the calendar year in which it ends.
column3: Prior to FY 1977, the U.S. fiscal year ran from July 1 through

column2: The three-month transition period in 1976 (July 1 through September 30) is treated as a distinct

column1: Foreign Assistance – defined in Section 634(b) of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961, as amended, as "...any
tangible or intangible item provided by the United States Government to a foreign country or international
organization under this or any other Act, including but not limited to any training, service, or technical advice, any
item of real, personal, or mixed property, any agricultural commodity, United States dollars, and any currencies of
any foreign country which are owned by the United States Government..." This section further states that
"...provided by the United States Government' includes, but is not limited to, foreign assistance provided by means
of gift, loan, sale, credit, or guaranty."
The executive agent and place of performance do not determine whether an official transfer is foreign assistance.
Such designation is based on whether foreign entities receive direct benefits from programs supported by USG
funds without paying for them. Most executive agents for USG assistance programs are U.S. entities. While
authorized primarily under FAA, USG foreign assistance is also authorized by other legislation. Similarly, USG
foreign assistance is primarily under appropriations within budget function 150, International Affairs, in annual
presentations of the Budget of the U.S. Government.

column2: Foreign Assistance = Economic Assistance + Military Assistance

column1: Grant – transfers of goods, services, or cash for which the recipient incurs no legal debt.
Loan – transfers for which the recipient incurs a legal debt and repayment is required over time, with or without
interest, in convertible currencies or in kind.
Military Assistance – foreign aid for programs primarily for the benefit of recipient government armed forces, or
aid which subsidizes or substantially enhances military capability.
Obligation – a binding agreement that will result in outlays, immediately or in the future.
be available before obligations can be legally incurred.
Deobligation – a cancellation or downward adjustment of previously incurred obligations. Deobligated funds may
be re-obligated within the same time period.
Net Obligations – the sum of new grant obligations and deobligations.
The country presentation is based on the organizational structure of the President’s Budget.
Program accounts are listed by their funding agency rather than the implementing agency when they differ.

The notes below pertain to selected countries and regions in the U.S. Overseas Loans and Grants report where
clarification is warranted. Since this report details development assistance over a period of more than sixty years, it
must also document changes to the countries of the world. In general, country names follow the short-form
names recognized by the U.S. Department of State in 2019; long-form names are in brackets.

Table of Contents. In effect, the Summary of All Countries is the worldwide total.

Serbia and Montenegro, Slovenia, Croatia, and The Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia all declared their
independence from Yugoslavia in 1991. In 1992, Bosnia and Herzegovina declared its independence and the
remaining republics of Serbia and Montenegro declared a new "Federal Republic of Yugoslavia" (FRY). The U.S.
Government subsequently provided assistance to each new country. In 2003, the official name changed from
Prior to 1993, data are reported under Serbia and Montenegro, Former. Beginning in 1993, Slovenia, Croatia, the
Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Bosnia and Herzegovina are reported separately.
In June 2006 Montenegro and Serbia officially declared independence and became independent countries. Data
prior to 2006 are included in Serbia and Montenegro, Former.

When Germany united in 1991, the combined Germany assumed all outstanding loans of the former West
Germany. West Germany was the recipient of all loan and grant assistance prior to 1991, except for $0.8 million in
Food for Peace (PL 480), Title II Emergency Relief grants provided to the Democratic Federal Republic of Germany
as Danube Food Assistance through the Red Cross in 1955.
